problem_text: Groups A and B are said to be locally equivalent if for every finitely generated subgroup X ⩽ A there is a subgroup Y ⩽ B isomorphic to X, and conversely, for every finitely generated subgroup Y ⩽ B there is a subgroup X ⩽ A, isomorphic to Y. We call a group G categorical if G is isomorphic to any group that is locally equivalent to G. Is it true that a periodic locally soluble group G is categorical if and only if G is hyperfinite with Chernikov Sylow subgroups? (A group is hyperfinite if it has a well ordered ascending normal series with finite factors.) V. V. Belyaev
